Posts.Title: Ray

Posts.Content: Fixit, Welcome to our caring family. Although you don't have an official "membership" yet and I truly hope you never get one, all are welcomed here. It is normal to be scared, so much goes through your mind when you're suddenly thrust into this as you were. The same thing happened to us. You're still trying to digest the fact that this could be happening to you and that's very understandable. It is important, very important, that you make the right decisions along the way even while you're still trying to figure out how this is happening in your life. IMO..One of the first of many of those very important decisions you need to make is the biopsy...please get the biopsy. You may even need another biopsy after the first. This biopsy could save your life. If there is cancer there you need to find it. We found my husband's after a 2nd biopsy that was an MRI biopsy. That one told us there was probable Extracapsular extension. I can't tell you how many nights I cried wishing we would have found it sooner, BEFORE it escaped the capsule. That's what you need to do. Start now, get the necessary tests to find out if it is indeed PCa and do them as soon as it makes sense. Trust me if it is PCa you'll be happier if you're able to look back and say we found it earlier rather than later because you made a smart, medically based/recommended decision. In our case, somehow by the grace of God, we did not have extracapsular extension. Yes, take the time you need to learn and digest and use the support and knowledge of the brave men on this forum as much as you need to, in whatever fashion you need to, but while you're doing that...Get the biopsy. God bless and best wishes. Hoping you will share your results if you do get the biopsy because these guys will be here to support you if you need them or congratulate you if it turns out there's no need!

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: Fixit, Welcome to our caring family. Although you don't have an official "membership" yet and I truly hope you never get one, all are welcomed here. It is normal to be scared, so much goes through your mind when you're suddenly thrust into this as you were. The same thing happened to us. You're still trying to digest the fact that this could be happening to you and that's very understandable. It is important, very important, that you make the right decisions along the way even while you're still trying to figure out how this is happening in your life. IMO..One of the first of many of those very important decisions you need to make is the biopsy...please get the biopsy. You may even need another biopsy after the first. This biopsy could save your life. If there is cancer there you need to find it. We found my husband's after a 2nd biopsy that was an MRI biopsy. That one told us there was probable Extracapsular extension. I can't tell you how many nights I cried wishing we would have found it sooner, BEFORE it escaped the capsule. That's what you need to do. Start now, get the necessary tests to find out if it is indeed PCa and do them as soon as it makes sense. Trust me if it is PCa you'll be happier if you're able to look back and say we found it earlier rather than later because you made a smart, medically based/recommended decision. In our case, somehow by the grace of God, we did not have extracapsular extension. Yes, take the time you need to learn and digest and use the support and knowledge of the brave men on this forum as much as you need to, in whatever fashion you need to, but while you're doing that...Get the biopsy. God bless and best wishes. Hoping you will share your results if you do get the biopsy because these guys will be here to support you if you need them or congratulate you if it turns out there's no need!

Posts.Title: Where is ForumBrother FeatherBoy?

Posts.Content: dth, Boy I'm so sorry you're learning about PSA this way instead of easing into it by getting regular PSA tests with results within range as part of regular annual physical exams/aging. The same thing happened to us so I understand. When we got our first PSA test results we didn't even know what the prostate does. I know you feel panicked so although I don't feel qualified enough to give you advise, I do want to tell you that you're in the right place to get help, guidance, and support. I promise you that our forum experts will be along soon to answer your questions. Meanwhile, can you give us your age? Any family history of prostate cancer? I know there are other things that can cause an elevated PSA I just don't know how high they can raise it so I'll defer to our experts. Don't automatically think the worst. Hang in there, I'm sure you'll get some answers anytime now.

Posts.Title: First PSA

Posts.Content: Hello! We can get through this together! My husband does eat a banana every day for breakfast along with a chocolate chip cliff bar. He was never a coffee guy but does wash down his breakfast with a PepsiOne every morning, which is his source of caffeine. We really don't drink alcohol so he's not had any of that. I was told veggies should be very, very cooked. We've really limited them along with fruits to be safe. He had a bout with C-Diff about a year before the cancer that landed him in the hospital for a week so I'm being overly cautious. Ever since then he's been taking probiotics twice a day, RO said it was fine to keep taking those. I can't tell you how hard it is for me to shop and cook this way. I'm usually all about the healthy selections, but we were told...no whole grains, brown rice... it's almost like I sneak through the grocery store because I'm embarrassed of what is or isn't in my cart lol! It's all worth it in the end if he continues to have no big issues.

Posts.Title: SRT without ADT - Quick Update

Posts.Content: I wanted to provide a quick update on how my husband is doing on his SRT. I titled it "Quick Update" because it will be quick due to the fact that there's not too much to tell. He has 11 more session to go so he's seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. As far as side effects I'd say the worst of it so far has been that he's tired. Not sure how much of that is from the treatment and how much is from racing around trying to do his job (pretty physical) and still make it to treatment, all while keeping up with the extra stuff life likes to throw your way. He said when he's done with treatment going back to his old life where he only has to work and not worry about making it to treatment on time will be like a vacation. That being said, as tough as it is he has never had a problem or missed a session. The nurses and techs are outstanding. If he gets there early and there's a way for them to fit him in they do it so he can be done and on his way home. I'm so thankful for the entire team we have there! He started on January 16th and is still doing great. Aside from being tired the only thing he has ever mentioned to the Dr. is a slight sense of urinary urgency that started right after the 1/2 way point. Nothing bad enough to do anything about, but the doctor said if it gets to the point that it really bothers him all he needs to do is take AZO twice a day. So far he hasn't needed to. After the first few treatments he said his skin felt a little like when you think you may have been in the sun too long (not like a sunburn, just tight) so he used the lotion they gave him twice a day, once in the AM and once in the PM. That feeling went away somewhere before the 1/2 way point and he stopped using it. We did make a big change to his diet before he started which took some getting use to for me. No whole grain anything, really pretty much white flour starchy items like rice, noodles, potatoes crackers and very limited veggies. No nuts or anything with a lot of fiber. Nothing that would stimulate his bowels incase the radiation was going to cause diarrhea or gastrointestinal issues. So far it has not. I think after treatment we'll introduce those foods back in but maybe slowly, as I know radiation is the gift that can keep on giving. It will be good to get back to a more healthy diet though. He also stopped taking all supplements/vitamins (except for the sleep aid I mentioned in another post). We didn't want anything with antioxidants interfering with letting the radiation do its job. All and all I think that's it. He's not getting ADT so we can't comment on that. The other day a reminder popped up on my calendar for his uPSA. It was an old reminder I had placed on my schedule. It would have been his 24 month from surgery uPSA (Surgery in Feb of 2017). We're obviously not doing it, but boy oh boy did those ANXIOUS thoughts and feelings run rampant through my mind and body as soon as it appeared! I'm so nervous for the first one we'll have to do after this SRT, what fun that will be, back on the PSA test train again, oh joy! I hope I didn't forget anything. Thank you to everyone here for your support and for sharing so much! R2F

Posts.Title: First PSA

Posts.Content: Hello! We can get through this together! My husband does eat a banana every day for breakfast along with a chocolate chip cliff bar. He was never a coffee guy but does wash down his breakfast with a PepsiOne every morning, which is his source of caffeine. We really don't drink alcohol so he's not had any of that. I was told veggies should be very, very cooked. We've really limited them along with fruits to be safe. He had a bout with C-Diff about a year before the cancer that landed him in the hospital for a week so I'm being overly cautious. Ever since then he's been taking probiotics twice a day, RO said it was fine to keep taking those. I can't tell you how hard it is for me to shop and cook this way. I'm usually all about the healthy selections, but we were told...no whole grains, brown rice... it's almost like I sneak through the grocery store because I'm embarrassed of what is or isn't in my cart lol! It's all worth it in the end if he continues to have no big issues.

Posts.Title: Just Got Back From Urologist For Results First Post-Op PSA Test

Posts.Content: ASA, All it says is Technique: MRI Prostate; with and without intravenous administration of 20cc of MultiHance, prostate coil was used. I did notice it says "Large ADC low" so I wanted to try to see what the ADC was but it is not on here anywhere either. I just read something that said there's a correlation between the ADC and Gleason so I wanted to check out the ADC number. I am prepared to hear that PCa was found and I am praying for a low Gleason, but I will admit that the invasion into the urethra has set me back. It's even harder because no matter how much I look, I'm not finding anything where I can read about others that had that. Does a PIRAD 5 indicate aggressiveness or just the likeliness of PCa? Thank you for always responding when I have questions here ASA.

Posts.Title: Sore testicles!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Rich2.0 Hi SDM, I experienced some soreness as well. It wasn't bad, but definitely noticeable. It disappeared gradually, so I really can't say for certain how long it took to subside. Maybe a month or so??? I honestly don't think it lasted much longer than that. I actually forgot all about it until I read your post. I think you'll be surprised how fast things heal. It's pretty major surgery so I think it's normal but I'll be interested to see if other guys experienced the same. Rich2.0, My husband also had 3+3 along with 5% Gleason 4. Posts.Title: Sore testicles!

Posts.Content: My husband had an MRI this morning followed by his 2nd biopsy which was 16 needles. The doctor that did this biopsy was not our usual doctor. He did not want to see me to answer any of my questions and would not let me in the room to talk to him so I need to ask if anyone here can help me interrupt this findings. We should get the biopsy results next week. PROSTATE SIZE: 4.6 x 3.3 x 4.7 cm PERIPHERAL ZONE: Diffuse dark signal in the left peripheral zone, this may represent prostatitis. CENTRAL GLAND: ADC low (series 303 image 344) and T2 low (series 201 image 59) focus measuring 1.6 x 1.0 cm in the right transitional zone. There is mild early arterial enhancement with washout. There is invasion of the right prosthetic urethra by this lesion (series 201 image 56). SEMINAL VESICLES: No evidence of seminal vesicle invasion. EXTRACAPSULAR EXTENSION: There is probable anterior extracapsular extension series 201 image 58 BLADDER: No significant abnormality noted. LYMPH NODES: No significant abnormality noted. BONES, SOFT TISSUES: No significant abnormality noted. OTHER: No significant abnormality noted. IMPRESSION: 1. Large ADC low and T2 low focus in the right transitional zone with invasion of the right prostatic urethra and probable anterior extracapsular extension. PIRADS 5 (I do know what the PIRADS 5 means, highly likely that this is PCa). He did tell us that obviously this is not the location that want to see the cancer in. The part that confuses me is that he did answer one question for me at the doorway after handing me a paper copy of this report. He told me the good news is that it looks to be contained within the capsule. When he said that I told him I didn’t understand because the report says probable extracapsular extension? He mumbled something about no, don’t worry about that or something like so I asked him if that meant surgery was still on the table and he said yes and then pretty much walked away. I’m not sure what to make of that, but what’s got me really upset, even before knowing the Gleason results is the invasion into his urethra. I would really, really appreciated any help the group can give me on this until we talk to our doctor next week.

Posts.Title: Need Help Interpreting MRI Results Please

Posts.Content: Carmel, I know exactly how you feel. I was in your shoes so I do relate to you for sure. When we first started this journey I would sit at my desk at work and just think this cannot really be happening, not to my husband, no way. Never in a million years did I think it would happen to him but it did. I had to give myself time to absorb the new reality of all of it. The hardest part was trying to keep myself together for his sake while I was around him. In order to do that I spent hours and hours right here with these brave men and women and as you can see...I'm still doing that. I don't think I can say it gets "easier" exactly, but it is doable. Yep there's lots of behind the scenes crying and your mind tries to take control but keep coming here and asking questions and take whatever support you're comfortable with from family, friends and coworkers. You have to be strong for him. Do your best to do that and I think you'll find strength in realizing that you're helping him by doing that. Be understanding with him no matter what he does or says and most importantly, be unrelenting in your pursuit of the best possible care, knowledge and any answers you need from your doctors. Ask questions, you are going to be his warrior/advocate so he can focus on doing what he needs to do. We will be here for you time after time, day and night! These guys did that for me and they will do the same for you. They know so much and no question is out of line so STAY STRONG...cry when you need to, but try not to do that in front of him. Prayers to you both and hope we'll hear back from you.

Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: Hi Tim. You should be seeing an RO now. Personally I wouldn't waste my time with a NP. Go right to the RO. Also want to add that just because you see the RO now that doesn't necessarily mean you'll immediately begin SRT. We were under the care of our RO only (no more URO at all) for a year before SRT was initiated. I think you need to find your RO and get in to see them to see how/if/when they would treat. I'm a big believer in having the right doctor for the job, with a rising PSA the next doctor you'll need is an RO. Go find them and get yourself under their care.

Posts.Title: Question - who do you followup with after RP surgery ?

Posts.Content: We didn't meet the RO for an entire year after surgery because like you, our pathology was decent (you even have a smaller margin at 1mm and ours is at the bladder neck) and his uPSA was low and remaining low. I was starting to think maybe we wouldn't have to. I would not beat yourself up over anything. If you were being tested to the lowest level of <0.03 who knows, it could have been slowing climbing to get where you are now. I don't know how much concern is placed on a uPSA under what you were testing at. Usually not a lot unless as you know, there's a true trend. With our high Decipher score we all agreed it would be prudent to treat now but who knows what your RO will say.

Posts.Title: Well, I just had another surgery

Posts.Content: For us our URO surgeon told us he didn't need to see us anymore. He said we could even just get our PSA tests through our family doctor. Once we had a slight rise on the uPSA that's when we connected with the RO. I was ordering the uPSA and paying out of pocket while we were with the URO surgeon. Once we started seeing the RO, she did give me the RX for the uPSA which was something the URO surgeon said he wasn't going to give me and he didn't want me seeking it out. During the year that his PSA was more or less "steady" while we were under the care of our RO and we thought things were going along somewhat uneventfully the plan was to either get an annual DRE from a local URO or our RO. We ended up getting the DRE from the RO.

Posts.Content: Carmel, I know exactly how you feel. I was in your shoes so I do relate to you for sure. When we first started this journey I would sit at my desk at work and just think this cannot really be happening, not to my husband, no way. Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: Hi Tim. You should be seeing an RO now. Personally I wouldn't waste my time with a NP. Go right to the RO. Also want to add that just because you see the RO now that doesn't necessarily mean you'll immediately begin SRT. We were under the care of our RO only (no more URO at all) for a year before SRT was initiated. I think you need to find your RO and get in to see them to see how/if/when they would treat. I'm a big believer in having the right doctor for the job, with a rising PSA the next doctor you'll need is an RO. Go find them and get yourself under their care.

Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: For us our URO surgeon told us he didn't need to see us anymore. He said we could even just get our PSA tests through our family doctor. Once we had a slight rise on the uPSA that's when we connected with the RO. I was ordering the uPSA and paying out of pocket while we were with the URO surgeon. Once we started seeing the RO, she did give me the RX for the uPSA which was something the URO surgeon said he wasn't going to give me and he didn't want me seeking it out. During the year that his PSA was more or less "steady" while we were under the care of our RO and we thought things were going along somewhat uneventfully the plan was to either get an annual DRE from a local URO or our RO. We ended up getting the DRE from the RO.

Posts.Title: Second Opinions for Advanced Prostate Cancer in the Chicago Area

Posts.Content: Hello Brite! From one PCa wife to another...Welcome to this most helpful and supportive place. I wish there was never a reason for us to gain new members, but I am so thankful to this group. So just as I expected, I don't think there's much for me to add. I was wondering about the proper doctor for you to seek because I know for my husband, we're in sort of a holding zone. By holding zone I mean we're still seeing our URO/Surgeon but that's just because his PSA is undetectable right now. BTW, for anyone reading this...we do both love his surgeon, Dr. Zagaja at the University of Chicago and can't say enough good things about him! That being said, if my husband's PSA ever begins to rise (PRAYING THAT DOES NOT HAPPEN) I know it would be time to see an RO. When I first joined this forum I got SO MUCH advice and support, it's pretty amazing. You really grow to care so much about the people here. MM16 was the one that got us to Dr. Zagaja when I was in a place of not knowing what to do. I took full advantage even before surgery, to ask MM16 a lot of questions and decided back then that we'd go to Dr. McCall if we enter BCR. I understand that you'd rather have something closer and what luck you're in to be so close to University of Chicago and Northwestern. It really stinks to be treated that way by a doctor you've placed so much trust in. You're really putting your life in their hands and to see them treat you like that after the fact sends chills down my spine! I'm sorry that is happening to you guys. IMO it's an absolute disgrace to add stress to any family facing any kind of cancer. Do you have any other info on your husband's pathology? Did they tell you the size of his margin or the Gleason at the margin? Your doctor also decided against a six week PSA?

Posts.Title: Second Opinions for Advanced Prostate Cancer in the Chicago Area

Posts.Content: ** Wanted to clarify my "something closer" comment. My thoughts on that are that if it's something you can possibly swing to see the best possible doctor then that's what should be done. You want the best possible chance at a cure! That brings about two questions in my mind: 1. Logistically can the commute really be done? It's not that the person is saying they just don't want to drive that far, it's a question of is it truly possible? The bottom line is you'll have to do it daily during ART/SRT and from what I've read it's almost a science of getting there and having a full bladder and coordinating all of that. I think you really do have to make sure it's possible. Trust me, I'd drive to the end of the earth for a cure for my husband --- it's a matter of figuring out can this really work if the doctor is worth it. This is also something MM has been through as far as the full bladder and timing all of it. If your husband is retired that will help since you could be more flexible with time I suppose. 2. It's going to come down to who "the best" doctor is in your own opinion. You'll do the research and take in all of the advice from everyone on the PCa support forums and then all you can do is make the decision that you both feel most comfortable with. It may be an RO at Northwestern, Loyola, University of Chicago or somewhere else. I think right now MM is right to suggest a consult with Dr. McCall or Dr. Szmulewitz to get started and see what they say. God Bless and always reach out if there's anything at all I can do to help!

Posts.Content: ** Wanted to clarify my "something closer" comment. My thoughts on that are that if it's something you can possibly swing to see the best possible doctor then that's what should be done. You want the best possible chance at a cure! That brings about two questions in my mind: 1. Logistically can the commute really be done? It's not that the person is saying they just don't want to drive that far, it's a question of is it truly possible? The bottom line is you'll have to do it daily during ART/SRT and from what I've read it's almost a science of getting there and having a full bladder and coordinating all of that. I think you really do have to make sure it's possible. Trust me, I'd drive to the end of the earth for a cure for my husband --- it's a matter of figuring out can this really work if the doctor is worth it. This is also something MM has been through as far as the full bladder and timing all of it. If your husband is retired that will help since you could be more flexible with time I suppose. 2. It's going to come down to who "the best" doctor is in your own opinion. You'll do the research and take in all of the advice from everyone on the PCa support forums and then all you can do is make the decision that you both feel most comfortable with. It may be an RO at Northwestern, Loyola, University of Chicago or somewhere else. I think right now MM is right to suggest a consult with Dr. McCall or Dr. Szmulewitz to get started and see what they say. God Bless and always reach out if there's anything at all I can do to help!

Posts.Content: Hello Brite! From one PCa wife to another...Welcome to this most helpful and supportive place. I wish there was never a reason for us to gain new members, but I am so thankful to this group. So just as I expected, I don't think there's much for me to add. I was wondering about the proper doctor for you to seek because I know for my husband, we're in sort of a holding zone. By holding zone I mean we're still seeing our URO/Surgeon but that's just because his PSA is undetectable right now. BTW, for anyone reading this...we do both love his surgeon, Dr. Zagaja at the University of Chicago and can't say enough good things about him! That being said, if my husband's PSA ever begins to rise (PRAYING THAT DOES NOT HAPPEN) I know it would be time to see an RO. When I first joined this forum I got SO MUCH advice and support, it's pretty amazing. You really grow to care so much about the people here. MM16 was the one that got us to Dr. Zagaja when I was in a place of not knowing what to do. I took full advantage even before surgery, to ask MM16 a lot of questions and decided back then that we'd go to Dr. McCall if we enter BCR. I understand that you'd rather have something closer and what luck you're in to be so close to University of Chicago and Northwestern. It really stinks to be treated that way by a doctor you've placed so much trust in. You're really putting your life in their hands and to see them treat you like that after the fact sends chills down my spine! I'm sorry that is happening to you guys. IMO it's an absolute disgrace to add stress to any family facing any kind of cancer. Do you have any other info on your husband's pathology? Did they tell you the size of his margin or the Gleason at the margin? Your doctor also decided against a six week PSA?

Posts.Content: We just did the 9 month uPSA for my husband and I think I let myself relax a little to much because it did catch me off guard. It came back at 0.014. He does have a margin so I have sort of always kept it in my mind that there's a good chance he'd enter BCR at some point, but I was thinking it might take longer since pathology said the Gleason at his margin was a 3. I guess I was just thinking Gleason 3 is slow growing so it might take a while. This isnt really that long since surgery. I set up a consult with an RO so we're under that care/keen eye of the doctor that we'd be with should we need to move forward with SRT. Be honest with me....how bad do you think this news is? I am devastated.

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think it's too early to call BCR with just one increase. That third decimal can IMO vary both for testing reasons and physiological ones. I posted some links in another two threads about uPSA and BCR. See Michael F's comments. I assume you doc wants to repeat the uPSA sooner than another 3 months. If you measure it twice in the same day you could get a variance. You need at least a couple of increases to call BCR. Stay calm. Some folks increase a bit and then stabilize at a still low level. Yes there seems to be a lot of BCR talk on the forums lately and I've been reading all of them even before we got this result. So thank you for posting that. This is a test we got/get at Labcorp on our own. Our doctor moved him to testing every 6 months after the last undectable he got through their testing which is not uPSA. So he (the surgeon) does not even know about this. I set up a consult with the RO in 2 weeks. I'll see what she says. You're thinking maybe retest sooner? Like 2 months from now?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think it's too early to call BCR with just one increase. That third decimal can IMO vary both for testing reasons and physiological ones. I posted some links in another two threads about uPSA and BCR. See Michael F's comments. I assume you doc wants to repeat the uPSA sooner than another 3 months. If you measure it twice in the same day you could get a variance. You need at least a couple of increases to call BCR. Stay calm. Some folks increase a bit and then stabilize at a still low level. Yes there seems to be a lot of BCR talk on the forums lately and I've been reading all of them even before we got this result. So thank you for posting that. This is a test we got/get at Labcorp on our own. Our doctor moved him to testing every 6 months after the last undectable he got through their testing which is not uPSA. So he (the surgeon) does not even know about this. I set up a consult with the RO in 2 weeks. I'll see what she says. You're thinking maybe retest sooner? Like 2 months from now?

Posts.Content: We just did the 9 month uPSA for my husband and I think I let myself relax a little to much because it did catch me off guard. It came back at 0.014. He does have a margin so I have sort of always kept it in my mind that there's a good chance he'd enter BCR at some point, but I was thinking it might take longer since pathology said the Gleason at his margin was a 3. I guess I was just thinking Gleason 3 is slow growing so it might take a while. This isnt really that long since surgery. I set up a consult with an RO so we're under that care/keen eye of the doctor that we'd be with should we need to move forward with SRT. Be honest with me....how bad do you think this news is? I am devastated.

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: We just did the 9 month uPSA for my husband and I think I let myself relax a little to much because it did catch me off guard. It came back at 0.014. He does have a margin so I have sort of always kept it in my mind that there's a good chance he'd enter BCR at some point, but I was thinking it might take longer since pathology said the Gleason at his margin was a 3. I guess I was just thinking Gleason 3 is slow growing so it might take a while. This isnt really that long since surgery. I set up a consult with an RO so we're under that care/keen eye of the doctor that we'd be with should we need to move forward with SRT. Be honest with me....how bad do you think this news is? I am devastated.

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by st3v3 My family GP found a prostate nodule last summer. Blood test showed PSA at 5.4. Biopsy came back at Gleason 9. A bone scan in September did not show cancer. I was referred to radiation oncologist who planned treatment after MRI and CT. Markers were placed in my prostate. The MRI revealed metastatic cancer in lower spine so a second bone scan was performed and showed metastatic cancer throughout my skeleton. At this point I was referred to a medical oncologist. I suspect and hope the first bone scan was read wrong. Even if my cancer is aggressive and has spread that much in just two months maybe chemo will knock it back. st3v3, Thank you so much for sharing and I too wish you success with your treatment and recovery. I hope you don't mind me asking the group this, but I'm wondering what they can share about your PSA being below 10, and still having metastatic cancer throughout your skeleton. I guess I was just assuming that you'd have to have a PSA much higher than 5.4 to have it spread to your entire skeleton. I have learned that the Gleason will vary and I've seen men with PSAs under 10 with Gleason 8 or Gleason 9 and also seen men with higher PSAs get lower Gleason results and while I'm still trying to figure that out or wrap my mind around the fact that there's just no rule about how that works, this thread is something new to me. I have seen where the lower PSA (really lower) results in the more rare ductal cancer (which I think is more aggressive?) but I'm really thrown for a loop by the fact that you can have extensive metastatic cancer with a 5.4. Is this common? st3v3, I'll keep you and your wife in my prayers, stay strong, you are not alone!

To go from <0.006 to 0.014 it has to be the PCa, what else could be generating that PSA?

Posts.Title: One year out and it was like it never happened

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by st3v3 My family GP found a prostate nodule last summer. Blood test showed PSA at 5.4. Biopsy came back at Gleason 9. A bone scan in September did not show cancer. I was referred to radiation oncologist who planned treatment after MRI and CT. Markers were placed in my prostate. The MRI revealed metastatic cancer in lower spine so a second bone scan was performed and showed metastatic cancer throughout my skeleton. At this point I was referred to a medical oncologist. I suspect and hope the first bone scan was read wrong. Even if my cancer is aggressive and has spread that much in just two months maybe chemo will knock it back. st3v3, Thank you so much for sharing and I too wish you success with your treatment and recovery. I hope you don't mind me asking the group this, but I'm wondering what they can share about your PSA being below 10, and still having metastatic cancer throughout your skeleton. I guess I was just assuming that you'd have to have a PSA much higher than 5.4 to have it spread to your entire skeleton. I have learned that the Gleason will vary and I've seen men with PSAs under 10 with Gleason 8 or Gleason 9 and also seen men with higher PSAs get lower Gleason results and while I'm still trying to figure that out or wrap my mind around the fact that there's just no rule about how that works, this thread is something new to me. I have seen where the lower PSA (really lower) results in the more rare ductal cancer (which I think is more aggressive?) but I'm really thrown for a loop by the fact that you can have extensive metastatic cancer with a 5.4. Is this common? st3v3, I'll keep you and your wife in my prayers, stay strong, you are not alone!

Posts.Title: Chemohormonal Treatment, PC Stage 4 D2

Posts.Content: So it could not find PSA below the limit of 0.006 but even if it was barely below that lower threshold at the last test, this was a pretty big jump to 0.014 in three months. I know we'll need several increases before any treatment will happen but that's what scares me at the same time. To go from <0.006 to 0.014 it has to be the PCa, what else could be generating that PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think it's too early to call BCR with just one increase. That third decimal can IMO vary both for testing reasons and physiological ones. I posted some links in another two threads about uPSA and BCR. See Michael F's comments. I assume you doc wants to repeat the uPSA sooner than another 3 months. If you measure it twice in the same day you could get a variance. You need at least a couple of increases to call BCR. Stay calm. Some folks increase a bit and then stabilize at a still low level. Yes there seems to be a lot of BCR talk on the forums lately and I've been reading all of them even before we got this result. So thank you for posting that. This is a test we got/get at Labcorp on our own. Our doctor moved him to testing every 6 months after the last undectable he got through their testing which is not uPSA. So he (the surgeon) does not even know about this. I set up a consult with the RO in 2 weeks. I'll see what she says. You're thinking maybe retest sooner? Like 2 months from now?

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: We just did the 9 month uPSA for my husband and I think I let myself relax a little to much because it did catch me off guard. It came back at 0.014. He does have a margin so I have sort of always kept it in my mind that there's a good chance he'd enter BCR at some point, but I was thinking it might take longer since pathology said the Gleason at his margin was a 3. I guess I was just thinking Gleason 3 is slow growing so it might take a while. This isnt really that long since surgery. I set up a consult with an RO so we're under that care/keen eye of the doctor that we'd be with should we need to move forward with SRT. Be honest with me....how bad do you think this news is? I am devastated.

I guess I was just thinking Gleason 3 is slow growing so it might take a while. This isnt really that long since surgery. I set up a consult with an RO so we're under that care/keen eye of the doctor that we'd be with should we need to move forward with SRT. Be honest with me....how bad do you think this news is? I am devastated.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I think it's too early to call BCR with just one increase. That third decimal can IMO vary both for testing reasons and physiological ones. I posted some links in another two threads about uPSA and BCR. See Michael F's comments. I assume you doc wants to repeat the uPSA sooner than another 3 months. If you measure it twice in the same day you could get a variance. You need at least a couple of increases to call BCR. Stay calm. Some folks increase a bit and then stabilize at a still low level. Yes there seems to be a lot of BCR talk on the forums lately and I've been reading all of them even before we got this result. So thank you for posting that. This is a test we got/get at Labcorp on our own. Our doctor moved him to testing every 6 months after the last undectable he got through their testing which is not uPSA. So he (the surgeon) does not even know about this. I set up a consult with the RO in 2 weeks. I'll see what she says. You're thinking maybe retest sooner? Like 2 months from now?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I go to get my blood work done on June 8th and my urologist office scheduled me to get the results on June 29th. I don't think that I can wait that long. Anyone else think that is an unusually long wait to get results? Oh my gosh, that is way too long to wait. I'm very surprised that they expect you to wait that long. We just did a blood test on our own and then our doctor wanted to run his own the following week. We viewed the results online within 24 hours in both cases. Good luck on your test and with getting your results in a more timely manner.

Posts.Title: Need your advice/suggestions ...

Posts.Content: Hello! We had a small Gleason 3 positive margin as well and after the first couple of undectable tests our surgeon also switched us to testing every 6 months. We were already getting our own uPSA tests so we continued on the 3 month schedule (I just felt more comfortable keeping a closer eye on it for at least the first year). Wouldn't you know it, on the very next test that we did on our own there was an uptick.

Posts.Title: Need your advice/suggestions ...

Posts.Content: A few weeks ago I got the best tip ever from Mikla. He told me where to order our own ultrasensitive PSA test online. I asked about it because we can't get the uPSA from our doctor and it was giving me A LOT of anxiety. So I used the site Mikla gave me and they use Labcorp so it was perfect! I did that and we got the results today, less than 24 hours after the blood draw. The process was incredibly simple start to finish. What did I love the most (aside from the great result)? The results came right to me as soon as they were ready! That was so awesome! No waiting for "the call". It was worth every last penny of the $109 cost, every last penny. Thank you Mikla!! The BEST part however is the result! <0.006! Phew, we're good for another 3 months. I'm going to enjoy the results today because I know the 90 countdown will begin for me the moment I open my eyes tomorrow. We'll see the doctor next week for his 3 month follow-up and my guess is that he'll still want to do his own PSA test as well. That test only goes as low as <0.05. Now for my question - I ordered the Labcorp test #140731 which is the uPSA w/o serial. Do I need to get the #140723 which is the uPSAwith serial? I can find the #140723 on the Labcorp site but not on the site I used to get this test without a doctor. Will the 140731 be ok to use going forward or do I need it with serial? This is a happy day for us and I'm very grateful to have everyone here supporting us - THANK YOU!

Posts.Title: He's in surgery now...

Posts.Content: So I have a question for you guys. With a 2mm Gleason 3 margin I thought we were more in the low risk category as well and now that we have the Decipher results we're in the high risk category. As much as I'd like to be back in the headspace I was in before having the Decipher results the truth is we're high risk now and I would not have known that without the Decipher test. Our URO Surgeon only tests to 0.05 which would not be good enough to warn us at 0.03 so I'm not understanding that at all. They also only wanted to test every 6 months even with a 75 Decipher. I guess that's really not a question exactly huh? My question is what do you put the most weight in: uPSA, Gleason, or Decipher? For us, we're on the same page as our RO which is different from the URO Surgeon, the trigger is 0.03. For DavefromMD, did he order the uPSA because your margin is 6mm?

Posts.Title: One Year Result, No longer zero, but in No Man's Land

Posts.Content: Hello LC. You remind me of my husband a bit in that he too has an elevated PSA but is not sure what to think, "we don't know if I have cancer or not" and he's right to say that because he has not yet been diagnosed. It's a confusing spot to be in. You're left wondering if the PCa is there and growing inside of you and are you making all the right moves to find it. One thing I have learned is that you have to be your own best advocate and if your gut is telling you something, go with it. You need to be able to have confidence in your doctor as you're putting these life saving decisions in his hands. Once you find the right doctor I feel like you know it because you're on the same page and that allows you to focus on the next steps. I'm not saying your current doctor is not the right doctor for you, just saying if you have doubts don't be shy about switching, you want the best warriors on your side if you are going to face this beast! We did find ourselves in this situation. Our first doctor was good with a good bedside manner and such but we just got the feeling we need someone better with much more experience. If other patients want to use him, fine by me, he was a great guy, but for my husband I had to be sure I did everything I could to connect with the best doctor and hospital that offers the best chance for a cure should he be diagnosed. Once we made that change I could physically feel a bit of relief that he was good hands (I mean that literally too since this will be his surgeon). As far as the stress of not knowing, it's so hard and each test with no diagnoses adds long stressful waiting periods. As great as it is to receive negative biopsy results, if the PSA remains elevated you're left wondering, do I have cancer, how bad is it, is it growing, should I be doing something different, something more? Did you have a free PSA test or any other types of tests like the PCA3 by chance? I wonder why you did not get the MRI with the 2nd biopsy? After my husband's negative 12 core (which I think is typically required by insurance first before you can get the MRI Fusion biopsy or any other better biopsy) we did change doctors and he said the next step would be an MRI and biopsy if he sees anything. The good thing is he does the MRI and biopsy the same day so no excruciating waiting between the MRI and biopsy. I really wish you luck, I know this is very tough. Please keep in mind that if you do have PCa it is treatable so keep doing what you're doing and make the best moves possible to find it as quickly as you can if it is there, that way you can focus on treatment and getting to the other side!

Posts.Title: One Year Result, No longer zero, but in No Man's Land

Posts.Content: I'm posting here because I'm concerned over my husbands PSA results. He is 48 years old and just had his first PSA test in June (at my request). It came back at 6.48 and we were sent to a urologist. We saw him right away. He did a DRE and said the left side seemed slightly enlarged, otherwise it was good. He told us to wait 30 days and re-test. He ordered a Total and Free PSA test and explained how that would provide us with better insight. While we waited the long and painful 30 days, I began reading this forum day and night. I can't stress enough how very grateful I am to all of you who dedicate so much time and truly care about those that post here. Sharing your experience and knowledge is priceless and you don't find support like this anywhere else online. For this, my sincerest thank you. You have helped to get me to a more positive place. I understand why they ask you to wait 30 days before you re-test but part of me feels it may actually be to allow you time to digest and prepare. That's what I did with the help of all of you. When we stated down this road I was not able to say the "C" word but I'm getting there slowly as I want to be prepared and be strong for my husband. He's not quite there yet, he's still in shock over the results of his 2nd PSA test. He was expecting it to come back way lower because the urologist told us it could be just a spike in his PSA. Because he never had PSA tests before the urologist has no history to work with. Second PSA test just came back and now it's 7.22. To make things more difficult, for some unknown reason, the lab failed to do the free PSA portion so we don't have anything to go on there. Urologist said he didn't want to bother waiting to retry for the free PSA and now we're scheduled for a 12 core in his office this Thursday. I'm ready to face what we need to face but my biggest concern right now is the rapid increase in his PSA. That's a very big jump for only 4 weeks. If the biopsy comes back positive I'm concerned what will happen while we wait the 6-8 weeks we need to wait before having it removed. Because he's still under a 10 PSA I like to think that we're catching it early but after reading post after post, his always seems to be higher than others. I do realize he's not been diagnosed yet but with a 7.22 PSA it almost seems inevitable. If it is, I pray we caught it early enough that it's contained. I'd love to have opinions on this big PSA jump for those of you that have been through this.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA Test Very Elevated Second Even Higher

Posts.Content: I'm posting here because I'm concerned over my husbands PSA results. He is 48 years old and just had his first PSA test in June (at my request). It came back at 6.48 and we were sent to a urologist. We saw him right away. He did a DRE and said the left side seemed slightly enlarged, otherwise it was good. He told us to wait 30 days and re-test. He ordered a Total and Free PSA test and explained how that would provide us with better insight. While we waited the long and painful 30 days, I began reading this forum day and night. I can't stress enough how very grateful I am to all of you who dedicate so much time and truly care about those that post here. Sharing your experience and knowledge is priceless and you don't find support like this anywhere else online. For this, my sincerest thank you. You have helped to get me to a more positive place. I understand why they ask you to wait 30 days before you re-test but part of me feels it may actually be to allow you time to digest and prepare. That's what I did with the help of all of you. When we stated down this road I was not able to say the "C" word but I'm getting there slowly as I want to be prepared and be strong for my husband. He's not quite there yet, he's still in shock over the results of his 2nd PSA test. He was expecting it to come back way lower because the urologist told us it could be just a spike in his PSA. Because he never had PSA tests before the urologist has no history to work with. Second PSA test just came back and now it's 7.22. To make things more difficult, for some unknown reason, the lab failed to do the free PSA portion so we don't have anything to go on there. Urologist said he didn't want to bother waiting to retry for the free PSA and now we're scheduled for a 12 core in his office this Thursday. I'm ready to face what we need to face but my biggest concern right now is the rapid increase in his PSA. That's a very big jump for only 4 weeks. If the biopsy comes back positive I'm concerned what will happen while we wait the 6-8 weeks we need to wait before having it removed. Because he's still under a 10 PSA I like to think that we're catching it early but after reading post after post, his always seems to be higher than others. I do realize he's not been diagnosed yet but with a 7.22 PSA it almost seems inevitable. If it is, I pray we caught it early enough that it's contained. I'd love to have opinions on this big PSA jump for those of you that have been through this.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA Test Very Elevated Second Even Higher

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone for your advice and encouragement, it gives me strength to get through these upcoming days. I've read so many posts from many of you and learned so much. I have also ordered Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. I would very much like to know what his free PSA was but since the lab didn't run the test and his PSA went up, I feel like it's a race against time. I know it's a "slow growing" cancer but during the 30 days we waited to get the FPSA it went up so much I almost wish we would have done the biopsy from day one. I'm afraid it's going to continue to rise rapidly especially during the wait for surgery (if necessary). I'll admit to being guilty as charged as far as focusing on the 30 day PSA increase but it was already so high for his age at 6.48. I was shocked when it went so much higher. I have a habit of thinking the worst so this is sending me over the top. Contributing to the problem is the fact that my husband was adopted so we know absolutely zero about his biological father. After reading everyone's stories and reading their signatures, it almost seems that once you're on this wheel it eventually gets you. It would be a blessing if his biopsy came back negative but to me, that would not mean we're in the clear. When I look at the history/signatures of the members here it looks like the biopsy results may come back negative and then many times 6 months or years later they come back positive. I also recall reading here that the 12 core can miss up to 20%? To your point Jim, you hit the nail on the head. If he has to have cancer, I'm very thankful it's a curable one. That is also how I explained it to our son. He's 27 so we filled him in on what's going on just so he's not blindsided and also so he's aware that we'll be keeping a keen eye on his prostate health as well going forward. I know all I can do right now is educate myself, try to be patient, and pray. Thanks so much, God bless.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH In my first act of urination -- after my catheter was removed one week after surgery -- I found that my urination ability had been restored to FIREHOSE levels, as when I was 16. Very forceful and powerful -- and I was almost 100% continent from the very beginning. Today, almost 6 years later, I still marvel at the difference before, and after, the surgery. And now, my garden hose nozzle is jealous of the forceful stream. It had better hope I don't decide to replace it out in the yard. LOL Same thing for my husband. His stream is so strong now that it actually woke me up from a sound sleep the other morning. That is a 100% true story.

Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Hello LC. You remind me of my husband a bit in that he too has an elevated PSA but is not sure what to think, "we don't know if I have cancer or not" and he's right to say that because he has not yet been diagnosed. It's a confusing spot to be in. You're left wondering if the PCa is there and growing inside of you and are you making all the right moves to find it. One thing I have learned is that you have to be your own best advocate and if your gut is telling you something, go with it. You need to be able to have confidence in your doctor as you're putting these life saving decisions in his hands. Once you find the right doctor I feel like you know it because you're on the same page and that allows you to focus on the next steps. I'm not saying your current doctor is not the right doctor for you, just saying if you have doubts don't be shy about switching, you want the best warriors on your side if you are going to face this beast! We did find ourselves in this situation. Our first doctor was good with a good bedside manner and such but we just got the feeling we need someone better with much more experience. If other patients want to use him, fine by me, he was a great guy, but for my husband I had to be sure I did everything I could to connect with the best doctor and hospital that offers the best chance for a cure should he be diagnosed. Once we made that change I could physically feel a bit of relief that he was good hands (I mean that literally too since this will be his surgeon). As far as the stress of not knowing, it's so hard and each test with no diagnoses adds long stressful waiting periods. As great as it is to receive negative biopsy results, if the PSA remains elevated you're left wondering, do I have cancer, how bad is it, is it growing, should I be doing something different, something more? Did you have a free PSA test or any other types of tests like the PCA3 by chance? I wonder why you did not get the MRI with the 2nd biopsy? After my husband's negative 12 core (which I think is typically required by insurance first before you can get the MRI Fusion biopsy or any other better biopsy) we did change doctors and he said the next step would be an MRI and biopsy if he sees anything. The good thing is he does the MRI and biopsy the same day so no excruciating waiting between the MRI and biopsy. I really wish you luck, I know this is very tough. Please keep in mind that if you do have PCa it is treatable so keep doing what you're doing and make the best moves possible to find it as quickly as you can if it is there, that way you can focus on treatment and getting to the other side!

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone for your advice and encouragement, it gives me strength to get through these upcoming days. I've read so many posts from many of you and learned so much. I have also ordered Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. I would very much like to know what his free PSA was but since the lab didn't run the test and his PSA went up, I feel like it's a race against time. I know it's a "slow growing" cancer but during the 30 days we waited to get the FPSA it went up so much I almost wish we would have done the biopsy from day one. I'm afraid it's going to continue to rise rapidly especially during the wait for surgery (if necessary). I'll admit to being guilty as charged as far as focusing on the 30 day PSA increase but it was already so high for his age at 6.48. I was shocked when it went so much higher. I have a habit of thinking the worst so this is sending me over the top. Contributing to the problem is the fact that my husband was adopted so we know absolutely zero about his biological father. After reading everyone's stories and reading their signatures, it almost seems that once you're on this wheel it eventually gets you. It would be a blessing if his biopsy came back negative but to me, that would not mean we're in the clear. When I look at the history/signatures of the members here it looks like the biopsy results may come back negative and then many times 6 months or years later they come back positive. I also recall reading here that the 12 core can miss up to 20%? To your point Jim, you hit the nail on the head. If he has to have cancer, I'm very thankful it's a curable one. That is also how I explained it to our son. He's 27 so we filled him in on what's going on just so he's not blindsided and also so he's aware that we'll be keeping a keen eye on his prostate health as well going forward. I know all I can do right now is educate myself, try to be patient, and pray. Thanks so much, God bless.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH In my first act of urination -- after my catheter was removed one week after surgery -- I found that my urination ability had been restored to FIREHOSE levels, as when I was 16. Very forceful and powerful -- and I was almost 100% continent from the very beginning. Today, almost 6 years later, I still marvel at the difference before, and after, the surgery. And now, my garden hose nozzle is jealous of the forceful stream. It had better hope I don't decide to replace it out in the yard. LOL Same thing for my husband. His stream is so strong now that it actually woke me up from a sound sleep the other morning. That is a 100% true story.

Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: I'm posting here because I'm concerned over my husbands PSA results. He is 48 years old and just had his first PSA test in June (at my request). It came back at 6.48 and we were sent to a urologist. We saw him right away. He did a DRE and said the left side seemed slightly enlarged, otherwise it was good. He told us to wait 30 days and re-test. He ordered a Total and Free PSA test and explained how that would provide us with better insight. While we waited the long and painful 30 days, I began reading this forum day and night. I can't stress enough how very grateful I am to all of you who dedicate so much time and truly care about those that post here. Sharing your experience and knowledge is priceless and you don't find support like this anywhere else online. For this, my sincerest thank you. You have helped to get me to a more positive place. I understand why they ask you to wait 30 days before you re-test but part of me feels it may actually be to allow you time to digest and prepare. That's what I did with the help of all of you. When we stated down this road I was not able to say the "C" word but I'm getting there slowly as I want to be prepared and be strong for my husband. He's not quite there yet, he's still in shock over the results of his 2nd PSA test. He was expecting it to come back way lower because the urologist told us it could be just a spike in his PSA. Because he never had PSA tests before the urologist has no history to work with. Second PSA test just came back and now it's 7.22. To make things more difficult, for some unknown reason, the lab failed to do the free PSA portion so we don't have anything to go on there. Urologist said he didn't want to bother waiting to retry for the free PSA and now we're scheduled for a 12 core in his office this Thursday. I'm ready to face what we need to face but my biggest concern right now is the rapid increase in his PSA. That's a very big jump for only 4 weeks. If the biopsy comes back positive I'm concerned what will happen while we wait the 6-8 weeks we need to wait before having it removed. Because he's still under a 10 PSA I like to think that we're catching it early but after reading post after post, his always seems to be higher than others. I do realize he's not been diagnosed yet but with a 7.22 PSA it almost seems inevitable. If it is, I pray we caught it early enough that it's contained. I'd love to have opinions on this big PSA jump for those of you that have been through this.

I would very much like to know what his free PSA was but since the lab didn't run the test and his PSA went up, I feel like it's a race against time. I know it's a "slow growing" cancer but during the 30 days we waited to get the FPSA it went up so much I almost wish we would have done the biopsy from day one. I'm afraid it's going to continue to rise rapidly especially during the wait for surgery (if necessary). I'll admit to being guilty as charged as far as focusing on the 30 day PSA increase but it was already so high for his age at 6.48. I was shocked when it went so much higher. I have a habit of thinking the worst so this is sending me over the top. Contributing to the problem is the fact that my husband was adopted so we know absolutely zero about his biological father. After reading everyone's stories and reading their signatures, it almost seems that once you're on this wheel it eventually gets you. It would be a blessing if his biopsy came back negative but to me, that would not mean we're in the clear. When I look at the history/signatures of the members here it looks like the biopsy results may come back negative and then many times 6 months or years later they come back positive. I also recall reading here that the 12 core can miss up to 20%? To your point Jim, you hit the nail on the head. If he has to have cancer, I'm very thankful it's a curable one. That is also how I explained it to our son. He's 27 so we filled him in on what's going on just so he's not blindsided and also so he's aware that we'll be keeping a keen eye on his prostate health as well going forward. I know all I can do right now is educate myself, try to be patient, and pray. Thanks so much, God bless.

He pretty much just said you need to come in for a biopsy. They didn't even tell us that he'd have to do an enema before. That was something I read on this forum and told him to call and ask about only to find out yes, he does indeed need to do that. We'll ask and see what he says.

Posts.Content: 261 Days Ago - I posted here for the first time. I was a disaster. I was lost and terrified. You all came to our rescue and got us through everything that at the time, I had NO IDEA we were about to go through. This brings me to where we are today. We found the cancer, had the surgery, 100% dry, back to work and better than ever, and the BEST NEWS yet... Today we joined the ZERO CLUB!!! 6 week PSA came back today = <0.01 I pray that it remains that way for the next test in May. Thank you all so much for everything! A special THANK YOU to Michigan Man who we had the pleasure of having lunch with a few weeks ago! GOD IS GREAT!

I honestly have been thinking of you over the past few weeks because I haven't seen you or a post from you I don't think in a while so I was getting concerned makes me so happy that on such a wonderful day for me I hear from you and know that all is well. That being said, I hope you are indeed doing great and thank you again for all of your support and kind words!

Posts.Content: I'm posting here because I'm concerned over my husbands PSA results. He is 48 years old and just had his first PSA test in June (at my request). It came back at 6.48 and we were sent to a urologist. We saw him right away. He did a DRE and said the left side seemed slightly enlarged, otherwise it was good. He told us to wait 30 days and re-test. He ordered a Total and Free PSA test and explained how that would provide us with better insight. While we waited the long and painful 30 days, I began reading this forum day and night. I can't stress enough how very grateful I am to all of you who dedicate so much time and truly care about those that post here. Sharing your experience and knowledge is priceless and you don't find support like this anywhere else online. For this, my sincerest thank you. You have helped to get me to a more positive place. I understand why they ask you to wait 30 days before you re-test but part of me feels it may actually be to allow you time to digest and prepare. That's what I did with the help of all of you. When we stated down this road I was not able to say the "C" word but I'm getting there slowly as I want to be prepared and be strong for my husband. He's not quite there yet, he's still in shock over the results of his 2nd PSA test. He was expecting it to come back way lower because the urologist told us it could be just a spike in his PSA. Because he never had PSA tests before the urologist has no history to work with. Second PSA test just came back and now it's 7.22. To make things more difficult, for some unknown reason, the lab failed to do the free PSA portion so we don't have anything to go on there. Urologist said he didn't want to bother waiting to retry for the free PSA and now we're scheduled for a 12 core in his office this Thursday. I'm ready to face what we need to face but my biggest concern right now is the rapid increase in his PSA. That's a very big jump for only 4 weeks. If the biopsy comes back positive I'm concerned what will happen while we wait the 6-8 weeks we need to wait before having it removed. Because he's still under a 10 PSA I like to think that we're catching it early but after reading post after post, his always seems to be higher than others. I do realize he's not been diagnosed yet but with a 7.22 PSA it almost seems inevitable. If it is, I pray we caught it early enough that it's contained. I'd love to have opinions on this big PSA jump for those of you that have been through this.

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone for your advice and encouragement, it gives me strength to get through these upcoming days. I've read so many posts from many of you and learned so much. I have also ordered Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. I would very much like to know what his free PSA was but since the lab didn't run the test and his PSA went up, I feel like it's a race against time. I know it's a "slow growing" cancer but during the 30 days we waited to get the FPSA it went up so much I almost wish we would have done the biopsy from day one. I'm afraid it's going to continue to rise rapidly especially during the wait for surgery (if necessary). I'll admit to being guilty as charged as far as focusing on the 30 day PSA increase but it was already so high for his age at 6.48. I was shocked when it went so much higher. I have a habit of thinking the worst so this is sending me over the top. Contributing to the problem is the fact that my husband was adopted so we know absolutely zero about his biological father. After reading everyone's stories and reading their signatures, it almost seems that once you're on this wheel it eventually gets you. It would be a blessing if his biopsy came back negative but to me, that would not mean we're in the clear. When I look at the history/signatures of the members here it looks like the biopsy results may come back negative and then many times 6 months or years later they come back positive. I also recall reading here that the 12 core can miss up to 20%? To your point Jim, you hit the nail on the head. If he has to have cancer, I'm very thankful it's a curable one. That is also how I explained it to our son. He's 27 so we filled him in on what's going on just so he's not blindsided and also so he's aware that we'll be keeping a keen eye on his prostate health as well going forward. I know all I can do right now is educate myself, try to be patient, and pray. Thanks so much, God bless.

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA Test Very Elevated Second Even Higher

Posts.Content: I'm posting here because I'm concerned over my husbands PSA results. He is 48 years old and just had his first PSA test in June (at my request). It came back at 6.48 and we were sent to a urologist. We saw him right away. He did a DRE and said the left side seemed slightly enlarged, otherwise it was good. He told us to wait 30 days and re-test. He ordered a Total and Free PSA test and explained how that would provide us with better insight. While we waited the long and painful 30 days, I began reading this forum day and night. I can't stress enough how very grateful I am to all of you who dedicate so much time and truly care about those that post here. Sharing your experience and knowledge is priceless and you don't find support like this anywhere else online. For this, my sincerest thank you. You have helped to get me to a more positive place. I understand why they ask you to wait 30 days before you re-test but part of me feels it may actually be to allow you time to digest and prepare. That's what I did with the help of all of you. When we stated down this road I was not able to say the "C" word but I'm getting there slowly as I want to be prepared and be strong for my husband. He's not quite there yet, he's still in shock over the results of his 2nd PSA test. He was expecting it to come back way lower because the urologist told us it could be just a spike in his PSA. Because he never had PSA tests before the urologist has no history to work with. Second PSA test just came back and now it's 7.22. To make things more difficult, for some unknown reason, the lab failed to do the free PSA portion so we don't have anything to go on there. Urologist said he didn't want to bother waiting to retry for the free PSA and now we're scheduled for a 12 core in his office this Thursday. I'm ready to face what we need to face but my biggest concern right now is the rapid increase in his PSA. That's a very big jump for only 4 weeks. If the biopsy comes back positive I'm concerned what will happen while we wait the 6-8 weeks we need to wait before having it removed. Because he's still under a 10 PSA I like to think that we're catching it early but after reading post after post, his always seems to be higher than others. I do realize he's not been diagnosed yet but with a 7.22 PSA it almost seems inevitable. If it is, I pray we caught it early enough that it's contained. I'd love to have opinions on this big PSA jump for those of you that have been through this.

Posts.Content: 261 Days Ago - I posted here for the first time. I was a disaster. I was lost and terrified. You all came to our rescue and got us through everything that at the time, I had NO IDEA we were about to go through. This brings me to where we are today. We found the cancer, had the surgery, 100% dry, back to work and better than ever, and the BEST NEWS yet... Today we joined the ZERO CLUB!!! 6 week PSA came back today = <0.01 I pray that it remains that way for the next test in May. Thank you all so much for everything! A special THANK YOU to Michigan Man who we had the pleasure of having lunch with a few weeks ago! GOD IS GREAT!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by garyi To add to that, I met with noted RO, Dr. Anthony D'Amico at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute two days ago. He said the with a G3+4, metastases is all but unheard of. IMHO, what's even worse than having PCa, is all the uncertainty and unnecessary angst it causes for so many of us. Thanks for sharing that. I would give anything to make that statement 100% true, I hope and pray that it is. I tried looking for further research or findings on that but didn't really find anything so I'm thankful to you for sharing his words. I'll take all the hope and positive thoughts I can get.

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Hello DW! It's the MRI you would want. If they find something they will know exactly where to place the biopsy needles. My husband was 48 when this all started for us and turned 49 1 week prior to surgery. After a negative 12 core biopsy he was able to get an MRI fused biopsy just as Michael F. mentioned above and thank goodness it found the cancer. We had to get the standard 12 core first because insurance would not pay for the MRI biopsy if we did not go through that step first I think that kind of stinks but we had no choice I would rather have just gotten the MRI biopsy right from the get-go. Good luck to you and please keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Hello DW! It's the MRI you would want. If they find something they will know exactly where to place the biopsy needles. My husband was 48 when this all started for us and turned 49 1 week prior to surgery. After a negative 12 core biopsy he was able to get an MRI fused biopsy just as Michael F. mentioned above and thank goodness it found the cancer. We had to get the standard 12 core first because insurance would not pay for the MRI biopsy if we did not go through that step first I think that kind of stinks but we had no choice I would rather have just gotten the MRI biopsy right from the get-go. Good luck to you and please keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Welcome PCH and thank you for sharing your story, it's a real eye opener! So if it is indeed a reoccurrence what has it been surviving on for ten years? I thought I've read that a Gleason 6 can't live without a prostate? Or am I confused and that's only that it can't live "outside" of a prostate? Still there is no prostate so 10 years is a long time to just be hanging out unless there's some benign prostate tissue remaining? I'd love to hear what you guys think. Good luck to you PCH and if you need us, we're all here for you!

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Hello brake. Welcome to your safe landing place! You can come here with all of your questions and concerns without worrying what people will think because we all understand and care about each other here and now you're stuck with us So I openly admit to being an EMEXTRE worrior which means I understand when you say you are numb. Nothing is the same once you get the diagnoses, until...you've had time to let it sink in, been through all of the testing, took your time and developed a plan of attack and put it into action. Then or maybe even at some point along the way things do start to become clearer and somewhat the same again. I guess you'd call it the new normal where you still worry over the next step but in between them you see the beauty of what you have at that moment and truly treasure everything. For you and your husband right now, keep checking in here and sharing with these fine fellows. They know so much and the more information you can provide them with the more they can and will help you. Your husband's PSA is not super high (my husband's was higher) and even though he's a Gleason 8 that in no way means a cure is not possible. Dont try to tackle everything all at once. Take it in phases and study up on what ever stage you're in and then onto the next. Diagnosis, treatment, recovery, aftercare.. I know as the caregivers we try to think of everything top to bottom all at once and that does not help anyone so don't feel like you need to know it all right now. That would be too overwhelming for you. I did this in the beginning and it made it very difficult for me to learn everything I was trying to study and read and read and read about everything all at once and it was too much to comprehend. I had to slow down and take it in chunks and focus on what we were dealing with at the moment trying to learn about diagnosis, treatment and biochemical reoccurrence all at the same time was way too much for me and was burdening me and my ability to care for my husband. I think I've ranted on long enough now. I really just want to convey to you that from one wife to another I understand what's in your mind and I am definitely here for you along with the other forum family members!

Posts.Content: Hello Joe. That's a good question that I'm sure someone here will have an answer to. I'd be curious to know the answer as well so I'll keep an eye on this thread. From what I've read the 4 rating indicates that the likelihood of the presence of cancer in the prostate is "high" if your score was 5 it would have been a "very high" likelihood. I don't know how the PI Rad score relates to the level of "aggressiveness" as a gleason would provide from a biopsy. I don't know if it's all relative, meaning if they score you at a high likelihood that means there's more of it, therfore it's "aggressive"? I don't know but thank goodness Friday is not that far off now and you'll be able to get the answers from your doctor. The waiting and the not knowing what's going on is very difficult for sure. Let's wait and see if anyone here can tell us.

Posts.Title: Pi-rads 4 / mri scan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic If you need an expensive test and unsure whether it will be covered by your insurance, I suggest contacting the company and asking what your max out-of-pocket cost would be if your are denied coverage but want to consider paying for it yourself. In my case the fee I had to pay was very small. Get the price in writing--I did, and it turned out the sales rep who emailed me the cost was no longer working at the company by the time I was denied coverage. They had not run the test, at which point I had to authorize it myself. (GenomeDx honored the amount agreed after I forwarded the email. I paid and they then requested tissue from my RP. This delayed everything by a month, but I got the test done in the end.) Yep! I agree Gary! This was very helpful to me! In fact, I did exactly as DJ suggested above and the folks at GenomeDx were more than helpful. I now have a plan in place in case our insurance denies the test to make sure we still get it done. I would not have known any of this without your post so THANK YOU!

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: Bad68, Welcome to the club and to this wonderful forum. Not so great to have the official club membership, I get that, but you'll quickly see how being here will help you and your wife. So my husband was 48 when diagnosed as well and he just had surgery in February. He is doing great! Please make sure to tell your wife this and I want to make sure you hear my message loud and clear as well because it's important that you know that you're doing the right thing and that neither of you should think of this as a death sentence. I feel silly saying that because I am admittedly still overly concerned to put it mildly (if that's really possible with cancer I'm not sure) but I have been told many many times that I need to relax so I can certainly most definitely relate to your wife that's why I feel it's a bit ironic for me to say this but I really do mean it...Your PSA is not super high and you're a Gleason 6. If you have to have PCa that's what you would want to be. How are you doing/feeling? Are you hanging in there ok? Just try to take this step by step it will maybe take a bit of time to absorb but you will be okay please know that. Keep checking back as more of our fine forum brothers will be responding to give you more insight from their point of view since I personally did not go through this I may not be able to share that but I definitely can relate to your wife so please update us on this site and tell your wife everything will be ok. If she ever needs anyone to talk to I am here for her. Sincerely wishing you the best, R2F Forgot to ask if you can tell us where you're located?

Posts.Content: Scott, have any of your PSA tests ever included a free PSA? Just curious because your case seems somewhat similar to my husband. But who knows it's so hard to tell what all of this means it's different for everybody and sometimes from one doctor to the next.
