Posts.Title: New Member of the "0" Club!!!!

Posts.Content: Hello brake. Welcome to your safe landing place! You can come here with all of your questions and concerns without worrying what people will think because we all understand and care about each other here and now you're stuck with us So I openly admit to being an EMEXTRE worrior which means I understand when you say you are numb. Nothing is the same once you get the diagnoses, until...you've had time to let it sink in, been through all of the testing, took your time and developed a plan of attack and put it into action. Then or maybe even at some point along the way things do start to become clearer and somewhat the same again. I guess you'd call it the new normal where you still worry over the next step but in between them you see the beauty of what you have at that moment and truly treasure everything. For you and your husband right now, keep checking in here and sharing with these fine fellows. They know so much and the more information you can provide them with the more they can and will help you. Your husband's PSA is not super high (my husband's was higher) and even though he's a Gleason 8 that in no way means a cure is not possible. Dont try to tackle everything all at once. Take it in phases and study up on what ever stage you're in and then onto the next. Diagnosis, treatment, recovery, aftercare.. I know as the caregivers we try to think of everything top to bottom all at once and that does not help anyone so don't feel like you need to know it all right now. That would be too overwhelming for you. I did this in the beginning and it made it very difficult for me to learn everything I was trying to study and read and read and read about everything all at once and it was too much to comprehend. I had to slow down and take it in chunks and focus on what we were dealing with at the moment trying to learn about diagnosis, treatment and biochemical reoccurrence all at the same time was way too much for me and was burdening me and my ability to care for my husband. I think I've ranted on long enough now. I really just want to convey to you that from one wife to another I understand what's in your mind and I am definitely here for you along with the other forum family members!

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Since the start of this process with my husband, I've been making my son promise to ask for a PSA test at his next regular visit to the doctor. My husband was adopted so we did not have the benefit of having knowledge of any family health history. I'm going to make sure PCa does not catch my son by surprise as it did us. It may or may not be in the cards for him, but we're going to stay on top of it so if it is, we'll catch it as early as possible. Our son is 28 years old. He just told his doctor about his dad and asked for a PSA test. His doctor told him that if our "specialist" (Dr. Zagaja at the University of Chicago) thinks my son is "at risk" he will go ahead and write a letter of opinion to try to get my son's insurance to approve a PSA test. My thoughts on this are: 1. The only way I can understand what my son's doctor is saying is because my husband has not yet been diagnosed (see my signature) but he didn't say that was the reason he needed to know what my husband's doctor thought. He said it's because my son is only 28. 2. Once a family history is established, i.e. my husband is diagnosed, then IMO, my son is at risk. 3. Despite the fact that he's only 28, I think he still needs to test his PSA so at the very least, he'll have a trend established. That was the first thing our doctors asked us. They wanted to know what my husband's PSA history was and we had no history. His first elevated PSA was the only PSA test he ever had. 4. We asked what the youngest patient our surgeon had ever operated on was and his answer was 32. I don't think 28 is too young to get a simple life saving blood test! 5. If insurance won't pay for it, we'll pay for it but at what point will insurance agree it's warranted? If his dad/my husband does indeed have PCa it will have to be approved at some point during his younger years. What's the age that insurance companies feel that our precious sons/grandsons can get this test? 6. Although it's not so common, I think men do get PCa in their 20's and I know they do in their 30's. Starting to test at the age of 28 even if it's just to establish a history, seems reasonable to me, especially if you don't know the history of your paternal grandfather and your father has PCa (once we have that confirmed). My son is going to discuss this with his doctor again face to face (initial conversation was on the phone via a nurse) so I told him to find out what exactly his doctor needs from our doctor and I will try to get it! I know I'm an overprotective wife and mother so...I'd like to know what you guys think. Am I overreacting by asking for a PSA test for our 28 year old son? All my best to all of you!

Posts.Title: Zero club renewed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gronskis I have been researching the (non-cancerous) reasons for elevated PSA, but I cannot find anything that seems to apply to my situation. My concern is that adenocarcinoma may still be lurking within the prostate, and has not yet been discovered in the three biopsies. My question to the forum members is where do I go from here? What are the next logical steps, medical tests etc. that I should take to determine what is actually causing these precipitous increases in PSA levels. Since you found Gleason 6 in 2 cores in 2013, have a family history of PCa, and your PSA is rising do you have the option of treatment now if you want it or does your doctor want to do another biopsy or other tests like a PCA3 before recommending treatment? I ask because I don't know what the "rules" are. Is it once they find the PCa you have the option of treatment including RP or does he have to find a certain amount of PCa before he gives the go ahead? Really just wondering if the decision is ultimately yours to move forward with treatment at any point after it's initially discovered or how that works?

Posts.Title: I never get used to it...(PSA-test-angst)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gronskis I have been researching the (non-cancerous) reasons for elevated PSA, but I cannot find anything that seems to apply to my situation. My concern is that adenocarcinoma may still be lurking within the prostate, and has not yet been discovered in the three biopsies. My question to the forum members is where do I go from here? What are the next logical steps, medical tests etc. that I should take to determine what is actually causing these precipitous increases in PSA levels. Since you found Gleason 6 in 2 cores in 2013, have a family history of PCa, and your PSA is rising do you have the option of treatment now if you want it or does your doctor want to do another biopsy or other tests like a PCA3 before recommending treatment? I ask because I don't know what the "rules" are. Is it once they find the PCa you have the option of treatment including RP or does he have to find a certain amount of PCa before he gives the go ahead? Really just wondering if the decision is ultimately yours to move forward with treatment at any point after it's initially discovered or how that works?

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsies but rapidly rising PSA

Posts.Content: Hello Gacabrini. I very much agree what those above are telling you. I also understand how difficult it can be to try to discuss this with someone that doesn't want to discuss it. Although my husband didn't want to talk about it, he was willing to move forward with tests and finding better/different doctors that were willing to do further tests. When I talk to people about what is happening to me now I ALWAYS tell them to test their PSA or the PSA of their loved ones. To my surprise many just say ok but it goes in one ear and out the other. I have learned over the past 6 months that we've been going through this why some do that. It's because they don't want to be in our shoes. It's the same reason why sometimes when people do get a negative basic 12 core biopsy they say oh thank goodness and they just move one while their PSA is still high. They think what they don't know can't hurt them, but if PCa is there and they ignore it, it can. They don't want to have to deal with it and they certainly don't want PCa to come true for them. Let's be honest, until it happens to you, you think that happens to other people, but not to me. Some people don't like to go to the doctor so if you do get lucky and get them to go, they just do what the doctor says and would never think to have an opinion of their own, let alone one that may go against what a doctor has told them. If I had a dime for every time I asked my husband to do something or consider this test, or this new doctor, or doing something else and he said to me "you're not a doctor", well, I'd have a lot of dimes but... I just let him say that because in the end he is willing to do it. If we were not married and he was on his own I can promise you he would not. Some people are just not like that. My dad said he'd be the same way, he'd just do strictly what his doctor told him. What the wonderful men on this forum are telling you is very important for both of you. You need to find a way to get him to let you in. He does need to become the patient and allow you to help. You'll need to do exactly what you're doing, research and try to find ways to allow you to help. His job will be to let the doctors do what they need to do because it could come down to saving his life and if it turns out to be an infection or BPH you'll just end up being very thankful and it will help you to realize how lucky you are to have each other. I think deep down inside my husband came to realize this was serious and he needed to do these things he never dreamed he'd have to (DREs and Biopsies). I also know a big part of his willingness to do them was to help me. I know that sounds crazy and wrong and it's something I feel bad about (the fact that I let my emotions show so much that it worried him), but at least it got him to move forward with the tests that found his PCa. Because he has the kindest heart ever and cares more for me more than himself, he was willing to because he saw how worried I was. The men here on this forum helped me to understand that it was not going to help him to see me like that so I am doing better with it. If your BF is not willing to do anything different for his own sake can you ask him to please do it for you? Your BF has a high PSA that needs to be better investigated soon rather than later. I think the guys here can make recommendations for excellent doctors and hospitals in your area if you ask. That's how I found out about where to take my husband. Wishing you strength while you stay on top of this and take care of your BF and yourself!

Posts.Title: Question from New User about my boyfriend's high PSA score

Posts.Content: Hello brake. Welcome to your safe landing place! You can come here with all of your questions and concerns without worrying what people will think because we all understand and care about each other here and now you're stuck with us So I openly admit to being an EMEXTRE worrior which means I understand when you say you are numb. Nothing is the same once you get the diagnoses, until...you've had time to let it sink in, been through all of the testing, took your time and developed a plan of attack and put it into action. Then or maybe even at some point along the way things do start to become clearer and somewhat the same again. I guess you'd call it the new normal where you still worry over the next step but in between them you see the beauty of what you have at that moment and truly treasure everything. For you and your husband right now, keep checking in here and sharing with these fine fellows. They know so much and the more information you can provide them with the more they can and will help you. Your husband's PSA is not super high (my husband's was higher) and even though he's a Gleason 8 that in no way means a cure is not possible. Dont try to tackle everything all at once. Take it in phases and study up on what ever stage you're in and then onto the next. Diagnosis, treatment, recovery, aftercare.. I know as the caregivers we try to think of everything top to bottom all at once and that does not help anyone so don't feel like you need to know it all right now. That would be too overwhelming for you. I did this in the beginning and it made it very difficult for me to learn everything I was trying to study and read and read and read about everything all at once and it was too much to comprehend. I had to slow down and take it in chunks and focus on what we were dealing with at the moment trying to learn about diagnosis, treatment and biochemical reoccurrence all at the same time was way too much for me and was burdening me and my ability to care for my husband. I think I've ranted on long enough now. I really just want to convey to you that from one wife to another I understand what's in your mind and I am definitely here for you along with the other forum family members!

Posts.Title: Question from New User about my boyfriend's high PSA score

Posts.Content: Welcome PCH and thank you for sharing your story, it's a real eye opener! So if it is indeed a reoccurrence what has it been surviving on for ten years? I thought I've read that a Gleason 6 can't live without a prostate? Or am I confused and that's only that it can't live "outside" of a prostate? Still there is no prostate so 10 years is a long time to just be hanging out unless there's some benign prostate tissue remaining? I'd love to hear what you guys think. Good luck to you PCH and if you need us, we're all here for you!

Posts.Title: I never get used to it...(PSA-test-angst)

Posts.Content: Dave, I'm glad you're doing so well! For the sleep issues, if you're looking to find some help with that consider trying L-Theanine PLUS Melatonin. It was recommended to us by our RO and I guess the key is having the L-Theanine with the Melatonin. After trying lots of things this seems to really work. My husband has to get up very early every day and this really doesn't interfere with that, he's not groggy or anything. I got him the Puritans Pride brand and its not very expensive at all. Keep on keeping on ! R2F

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Hello Joe. That's a good question that I'm sure someone here will have an answer to. I'd be curious to know the answer as well so I'll keep an eye on this thread. From what I've read the 4 rating indicates that the likelihood of the presence of cancer in the prostate is "high" if your score was 5 it would have been a "very high" likelihood. I don't know how the PI Rad score relates to the level of "aggressiveness" as a gleason would provide from a biopsy. I don't know if it's all relative, meaning if they score you at a high likelihood that means there's more of it, therfore it's "aggressive"? I don't know but thank goodness Friday is not that far off now and you'll be able to get the answers from your doctor. The waiting and the not knowing what's going on is very difficult for sure. Let's wait and see if anyone here can tell us.

Posts.Title: Wife in full remission

Posts.Content: Bad68, Welcome to the club and to this wonderful forum. Not so great to have the official club membership, I get that, but you'll quickly see how being here will help you and your wife. So my husband was 48 when diagnosed as well and he just had surgery in February. He is doing great! Please make sure to tell your wife this and I want to make sure you hear my message loud and clear as well because it's important that you know that you're doing the right thing and that neither of you should think of this as a death sentence. I feel silly saying that because I am admittedly still overly concerned to put it mildly (if that's really possible with cancer I'm not sure) but I have been told many many times that I need to relax so I can certainly most definitely relate to your wife that's why I feel it's a bit ironic for me to say this but I really do mean it...Your PSA is not super high and you're a Gleason 6. If you have to have PCa that's what you would want to be. How are you doing/feeling? Are you hanging in there ok? Just try to take this step by step it will maybe take a bit of time to absorb but you will be okay please know that. Keep checking back as more of our fine forum brothers will be responding to give you more insight from their point of view since I personally did not go through this I may not be able to share that but I definitely can relate to your wife so please update us on this site and tell your wife everything will be ok. If she ever needs anyone to talk to I am here for her. Sincerely wishing you the best, R2F Forgot to ask if you can tell us where you're located?

Posts.Title: 48 y/o Newbie

Posts.Content: Scott, have any of your PSA tests ever included a free PSA? Just curious because your case seems somewhat similar to my husband. He too felt that he was going to the washroom more often during the day and at times with an increased sense of urgency and uses the washroom once maybe twice during the night. Both of our urologists said that really wasn't that much over the average. They pretty much didn't pay that much attention to it at best they asked him how much water he drinks and I guess he was drinking a fair amount so that's what they attributed it to. But who knows it's so hard to tell what all of this means it's different for everybody and sometimes from one doctor to the next.

Posts.Title: First post, elevated PSA reading today

Posts.Content: Thanks for your replies guys. That's amazing, I had no idea an immunization against prostate cancer was even on the horizon. I think part of the reason why I was so bothered by having to justify the PSA test for my son could be caused in part by the reaction I think we sometimes run into when anyone under the age of 50 wants a PSA test. Even our original family doctor kind of smiled and grinned like I was crazy when I asked for one for my 48 year old husband. I think the world should be just as aware of PSA/PCa for men as they are about breast cancer for us! Thanks so much I feel better knowing we can just go in and get the test without a doctor requesting it. Maybe I'll give it to him for Christmas kinda like I put a 6 week ACT preparation class under the tree for him while he was in high school lol! Trinity, thanks for sharing what your doctor said about testing your sons at age 35. That does help me to worry less.

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Since the start of this process with my husband, I've been making my son promise to ask for a PSA test at his next regular visit to the doctor. My husband was adopted so we did not have the benefit of having knowledge of any family health history. I'm going to make sure PCa does not catch my son by surprise as it did us. It may or may not be in the cards for him, but we're going to stay on top of it so if it is, we'll catch it as early as possible. Our son is 28 years old. He just told his doctor about his dad and asked for a PSA test. His doctor told him that if our "specialist" (Dr. Zagaja at the University of Chicago) thinks my son is "at risk" he will go ahead and write a letter of opinion to try to get my son's insurance to approve a PSA test. My thoughts on this are: 1. The only way I can understand what my son's doctor is saying is because my husband has not yet been diagnosed (see my signature) but he didn't say that was the reason he needed to know what my husband's doctor thought. He said it's because my son is only 28. 2. Once a family history is established, i.e. my husband is diagnosed, then IMO, my son is at risk. 3. Despite the fact that he's only 28, I think he still needs to test his PSA so at the very least, he'll have a trend established. That was the first thing our doctors asked us. They wanted to know what my husband's PSA history was and we had no history. His first elevated PSA was the only PSA test he ever had. 4. We asked what the youngest patient our surgeon had ever operated on was and his answer was 32. I don't think 28 is too young to get a simple life saving blood test! 5. If insurance won't pay for it, we'll pay for it but at what point will insurance agree it's warranted? If his dad/my husband does indeed have PCa it will have to be approved at some point during his younger years. What's the age that insurance companies feel that our precious sons/grandsons can get this test? 6. Although it's not so common, I think men do get PCa in their 20's and I know they do in their 30's. Starting to test at the age of 28 even if it's just to establish a history, seems reasonable to me, especially if you don't know the history of your paternal grandfather and your father has PCa (once we have that confirmed). My son is going to discuss this with his doctor again face to face (initial conversation was on the phone via a nurse) so I told him to find out what exactly his doctor needs from our doctor and I will try to get it! I know I'm an overprotective wife and mother so...I'd like to know what you guys think. Am I overreacting by asking for a PSA test for our 28 year old son? All my best to all of you!

Posts.Title: PSA Testing for our Sons & Grandsons

Posts.Content: Thanks for your replies guys. That's amazing, I had no idea an immunization against prostate cancer was even on the horizon. I think part of the reason why I was so bothered by having to justify the PSA test for my son could be caused in part by the reaction I think we sometimes run into when anyone under the age of 50 wants a PSA test. Even our original family doctor kind of smiled and grinned like I was crazy when I asked for one for my 48 year old husband. I think the world should be just as aware of PSA/PCa for men as they are about breast cancer for us! Thanks so much I feel better knowing we can just go in and get the test without a doctor requesting it. Maybe I'll give it to him for Christmas kinda like I put a 6 week ACT preparation class under the tree for him while he was in high school lol! Trinity, thanks for sharing what your doctor said about testing your sons at age 35. That does help me to worry less.

Posts.Title: Question about biopsy changes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gronskis I have been researching the (non-cancerous) reasons for elevated PSA, but I cannot find anything that seems to apply to my situation. My concern is that adenocarcinoma may still be lurking within the prostate, and has not yet been discovered in the three biopsies. My question to the forum members is where do I go from here? What are the next logical steps, medical tests etc. that I should take to determine what is actually causing these precipitous increases in PSA levels. Since you found Gleason 6 in 2 cores in 2013, have a family history of PCa, and your PSA is rising do you have the option of treatment now if you want it or does your doctor want to do another biopsy or other tests like a PCA3 before recommending treatment? I ask because I don't know what the "rules" are. Is it once they find the PCa you have the option of treatment including RP or does he have to find a certain amount of PCa before he gives the go ahead? Really just wondering if the decision is ultimately yours to move forward with treatment at any point after it's initially discovered or how that works?

Posts.Title: Full bladder

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman Great report. While it would be better to hve negative margins, it is very good news tht the positive margin was a grade 3. Low likelihood of it developing into something. Good sign that he's able to stop and start urine stream. I was able to as well, and by week 5 , I was going without pads. Expect recovervto full continence to not be linear. It will be 2 good days, one pad day. I weighed my pads and kept a journal of how much I leaked each day. That lowed me to see the progress week to week. Good luck with the recovery Thank your for your reply! I don't think I'd be able to sleep tonight without receiving opinions for our experienced users here so I really appreciate it. That's a great idea to weigh the pads! I will purchase a scale this weekend.

Posts.Title: First time for me

Posts.Content: Hello to all of my friends! Well I've been away for awhile but still reading everything here. I have also had the pleasure of keeping in touch with Michigan Man because he is so thoughtful of all of us here, he was checking in on me. I had many people in my life dx with cancer since I last posted and with the huge amount of worry over what my husband's final pathology was going to say I decided it might be a good idea for me to try to take a step back. I was very, very worried about the probable extracapsular extension noted in the MRI. I tried to stay quite until after the surgery when I knew what I was dealing with. Surgery was this past Wednesday and went very smooth. The only surprise was how swollen his face was when I saw him in recovery. It got better the next morning and luckily they warned me before he went to the OR that this could happen from the position he would be in during surgery. I received several updates as the surgery progressed and I cried happy tears when they called and gave me the update saying "the prostate is out". We met with the surgeon in the consult room after surgery. He told me he spared both nerve bundles and the surgery was pretty much text book. He said he did not think it escaped the capsule and there was less cancer than expected. He was honest and warned us that the devil is in the details and as all of us here know, we must wait for the final pathology. He shook the hands of all of my family that was in the room with us and I got to hug him in place of the handshake. It was important to me to hug the man that likely just saved my husband's life. He was the one that helped me find that cancer and the man that took it out. I needed to let him know how thankful my entire family is. I just cannot say enough about our Doctor, Dr. Zagaja. He has always taken the time to talk to us for as long as we need and ALWAYS makes you feel like he's just one person talking to another. He is kind and doesn't sugar coat anything. He talked with us the morning after the surgery and we were able to ask him everything and anything and never once felt rushed or that we were asking silly questions (and trust me I really do ask A LOT of questions!!). As soon as my husband got to his room out of recovery that night he ate a turkey sandwich and the night was uneventful. We had THE BEST NURSE EVER and I know that made a big difference for us throughout the night. He got up and started walking at about 2 am and by 9 am we were taking lots of trips up and down the hallway together. If our nurse, Stephanie happened to see us while we were on a walk she would dance and sing all the way down the hallway. He started passing gas right on schedule after that and we went home at about 11:00 am. The catheter was a total non-issue. Easy to keep clean and shower with and honestly was not a problem at all. He never had a single issue with it. NOTE ON THE RECLINER....that was one of the best tips I got here so THANK YOU! He would get up and take his walks around the house and was always happy to return to the recliner. We purchased one that is electric and reclines all the way back like a bed. It was very much like a hospital bed and he could keep it at whatever angle he wanted. I think he took one pain pill and then just used Advil and Tylenol. They gave us an RX for stool softener at the hospital (to save us some $$) and the doctor told him to take it 3 times a day. If he didn't have a BM by the end of the next day he said to take Maalox and the secret is to chase the Maalox with a cup of either something very hot or very cold. We did that and it worked like magic. BM was not painful and he's been going just as he usually does ever since. He is still taking 3 stool softeners a day. Today was the big day, the catheter removal! Another smooth event. Appointment was a 8:30 am and we were there early (of course!) they took us in, I asked A LOT of questions and they took out the catheter. I think we were back heading down Lake Shore Drive within an hour. When we were there the pathology was not ready yet but Matt, our wonderful PA promised to keep checking throughout the morning because by now he knows how much I worry. So far my husband has been able to urinate on his own. When he thinks he needs to go he gets up and seems to make it to the bathroom in time. It starts with a few dribbles and then he pretty much goes like he use to. We both comment each and every time that this does not mean he's not going to have a long road ahead of him. We say that because we honestly don't know what this means, we're braced for the worse case and are just happy that so far it's gone well (it meaning his ability to urinate). He said he tested and he is able to start and stop his stream by doing a Kegel. So now on to the pathology. We got a call with the results a few hours ago. Good news with the exception of the fact that we have a margin. I'm so happy that there was NOT any extracapsular extension but we do have a 2mm margin I think at the bladder? Is the bladder neck at the base? My question now is does anyone know if a 2mm margin is focal? And can I take any comfort in the fact that the Gleason at the margin is a Gleason 3? Here's a summary of the Pathology: Gleason score 7 (3+4) The Gleason grade 4 component is 5% of the entire tumor volume Prostate: 32.7 gm (without appendages)Tumor Volume Estimate: 35% No extraprostatic extension present and No lymphovascular invasion present Seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia, no tumor present High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) Thirteen lymph nodes, no tumor present (0/13) Perineural Invasion: Present The tumor involves proximal (basilar) margin for an added length of 2.0 mm tumor at the margin is Gleason 3 pT2cN0

Low likelihood of it developing into something. Good sign that he's able to stop and start urine stream. I was able to as well, and by week 5 , I was going without pads. Expect recovervto full continence to not be linear. It will be 2 good days, one pad day. I weighed my pads and kept a journal of how much I leaked each day. That lowed me to see the progress week to week. Good luck with the recovery Thank your for your reply! I don't think I'd be able to sleep tonight without receiving opinions for our experienced users here so I really appreciate it. That's a great idea to weigh the pads! I will purchase a scale this weekend.

Posts.Title: Update and Final Pathology

Posts.Content: Hello to all of my friends! Well I've been away for awhile but still reading everything here. I have also had the pleasure of keeping in touch with Michigan Man because he is so thoughtful of all of us here, he was checking in on me. I had many people in my life dx with cancer since I last posted and with the huge amount of worry over what my husband's final pathology was going to say I decided it might be a good idea for me to try to take a step back. I was very, very worried about the probable extracapsular extension noted in the MRI. I tried to stay quite until after the surgery when I knew what I was dealing with. Surgery was this past Wednesday and went very smooth. The only surprise was how swollen his face was when I saw him in recovery. It got better the next morning and luckily they warned me before he went to the OR that this could happen from the position he would be in during surgery. I received several updates as the surgery progressed and I cried happy tears when they called and gave me the update saying "the prostate is out". We met with the surgeon in the consult room after surgery. He told me he spared both nerve bundles and the surgery was pretty much text book. He said he did not think it escaped the capsule and there was less cancer than expected. He was honest and warned us that the devil is in the details and as all of us here know, we must wait for the final pathology. He shook the hands of all of my family that was in the room with us and I got to hug him in place of the handshake. It was important to me to hug the man that likely just saved my husband's life. He was the one that helped me find that cancer and the man that took it out. I needed to let him know how thankful my entire family is. I just cannot say enough about our Doctor, Dr. Zagaja. He has always taken the time to talk to us for as long as we need and ALWAYS makes you feel like he's just one person talking to another. He is kind and doesn't sugar coat anything. He talked with us the morning after the surgery and we were able to ask him everything and anything and never once felt rushed or that we were asking silly questions (and trust me I really do ask A LOT of questions!!). As soon as my husband got to his room out of recovery that night he ate a turkey sandwich and the night was uneventful. We had THE BEST NURSE EVER and I know that made a big difference for us throughout the night. He got up and started walking at about 2 am and by 9 am we were taking lots of trips up and down the hallway together. If our nurse, Stephanie happened to see us while we were on a walk she would dance and sing all the way down the hallway. He started passing gas right on schedule after that and we went home at about 11:00 am. The catheter was a total non-issue. Easy to keep clean and shower with and honestly was not a problem at all. He never had a single issue with it. NOTE ON THE RECLINER....that was one of the best tips I got here so THANK YOU! He would get up and take his walks around the house and was always happy to return to the recliner. We purchased one that is electric and reclines all the way back like a bed. It was very much like a hospital bed and he could keep it at whatever angle he wanted. I think he took one pain pill and then just used Advil and Tylenol. They gave us an RX for stool softener at the hospital (to save us some $$) and the doctor told him to take it 3 times a day. If he didn't have a BM by the end of the next day he said to take Maalox and the secret is to chase the Maalox with a cup of either something very hot or very cold. We did that and it worked like magic. BM was not painful and he's been going just as he usually does ever since. He is still taking 3 stool softeners a day. Today was the big day, the catheter removal! Another smooth event. Appointment was a 8:30 am and we were there early (of course!) they took us in, I asked A LOT of questions and they took out the catheter. I think we were back heading down Lake Shore Drive within an hour. When we were there the pathology was not ready yet but Matt, our wonderful PA promised to keep checking throughout the morning because by now he knows how much I worry. So far my husband has been able to urinate on his own. When he thinks he needs to go he gets up and seems to make it to the bathroom in time. It starts with a few dribbles and then he pretty much goes like he use to. We both comment each and every time that this does not mean he's not going to have a long road ahead of him. We say that because we honestly don't know what this means, we're braced for the worse case and are just happy that so far it's gone well (it meaning his ability to urinate). He said he tested and he is able to start and stop his stream by doing a Kegel. So now on to the pathology. We got a call with the results a few hours ago. Good news with the exception of the fact that we have a margin. I'm so happy that there was NOT any extracapsular extension but we do have a 2mm margin I think at the bladder? Is the bladder neck at the base? My question now is does anyone know if a 2mm margin is focal? And can I take any comfort in the fact that the Gleason at the margin is a Gleason 3? Here's a summary of the Pathology: Gleason score 7 (3+4) The Gleason grade 4 component is 5% of the entire tumor volume Prostate: 32.7 gm (without appendages)Tumor Volume Estimate: 35% No extraprostatic extension present and No lymphovascular invasion present Seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia, no tumor present High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) Thirteen lymph nodes, no tumor present (0/13) Perineural Invasion: Present The tumor involves proximal (basilar) margin for an added length of 2.0 mm tumor at the margin is Gleason 3 pT2cN0

Posts.Content: Oh no not at all trust me I've read everything here...i can take it. I am thankful for every post I read as it educates me! I am happy that it's good news for you! I'm just trying to keep it real for my situation so I don't allow myself to be blindsided by what is coming. Bottom line is I'm glad you posted because I learned from it!

Posts.Content: Nrhk2, I am so very sorry for your loss. Your father is no longer suffering and my bet is he would not want you suffering either. Allow yourself to grieve without guilt. That's what a parent would want for their child. I never really had parents that were involved in my life. Try to think about the good times you had with your dad and what a blessing it was to have him while you did. Hopefully you'll keep the memories of the happy times, when he was strong and full of energy in your mind and also remember the strength he must have shown to fight this battle. Keep that memory, the memory of your Warrior dad in your heart and honor him by becoming strong again, whenever that time might be. Don't rush, give yourself time to grieve but please don't punish yourself. God bless you and your father.

Posts.Title: Dad passed away finally on June 9

Posts.Content: mtbrdad, We were lucky enough to receive help from MM16 (and so many others here) when we were first blindsided with my husband's diagnosis. MM recommended that we check out Dr. Zagaja at the University of Chicago and that's exactly what we did. I hope you will look into a consultation with him as well. I can't say enough good things about him. If you meet with him I'm sure you'll see what I'm talking about. My husband had surgery with Dr. Zagaja in February and so far so good. Wishing you the best, R2F

Posts.Title: Three consecutive 0.0 PSA's ... No More Lupron, WooHoo!

Posts.Content: Me2, My husband's tumor was located within the TZ. His first biopsy came back completely negative because a typical 12 core doesn't reach into the TZ where his pretty sizable tumor was located. Thank goodness we didn't just take that negative biopsy and walk away. We were able to get an MRI which came back a PIRADS 5 and our URO/Surgeon has a partner that does all of the biopsies so he's very good at them. He was able to biopsy the TZ and the entire process took about 20 minutes from the time he left the waiting room to the time he was done (the biopsy, not the MRI). My husband said that this biopsy felt different from the first standard 12 core since the needles where reaching the TZ. He said he felt them more in his penis and that's because the tumor was seen at the urethra so that's where the doctor was able to stick the needles. He still said it wasn't that awful, did he enjoy it...NO, of course not, but still he said he's been through worse. For the benefit of others reading this that may be starting this process, I'd like to quickly add that at the UofC they made it as easy as they could for us by scheduling the MRI in the AM and getting the results to their urology department by early afternoon for the biopsy. We were able to get this done in one day. When I saw the biopsy results, I was panicked over the fact that the tumor had already gotten to his urethra. I didn't know what would happen because I really hadn't started to research that part yet. I was still focused on how to find out if he had PCa or not. In my mind I was thinking oh my gosh, are they going to have to give him some sort of new urethra, can they even do that?? I was going crazy and my mind was really working against me. When I talked to the PA about the biopsy results he told me that the part of the urethra that the PCa was in was a section of the urethra that they remove during surgery anyway. It went from the top of my worry list to the bottom. I do agree with the others that say you should try not to put the cart ahead of the horse (Yep, I know how hard that is to do,when people here said that to me it went in one ear and out the other, but if you can, PLEASE do try to take it one step at a time and wait to see exactly what you're dealing with). The reason I wrote everything above is not to bring your mind to a place that you don't need to be at yet. I wrote it because as we all know, lots of people read this forum so if it's something that may be helpful to someone that's at a point that my husband and I were at almost a year ago (MRI and TZ biopsy happened 3 days before Christmas), I want to share.
